original_title: Expected dips in interest rates positively impact investor sentiment in share market
original_body_lines: The stock market investor sentiment notably improved yesterday with the anticipation that interest rates would come down. Besides the debt restructuring process with bond dealers was reportedly going off smoothly. These developments positively impacted banking sector counters in the share market, analysts said.

In September, Sri Lanka experienced deflation for the first time since 2015, with the general price level falling below that of a year ago. This decline was driven by administrative price adjustments that brought down key cost drivers, including food, fuel, and water tariffs. This situation would considerably impact interest rates, market analysts added.

Both food and non-food inflation turned negative, contributing to the overall deflationary trend. Despite this, annual average inflation remains positive, reflecting elevated price levels from earlier months. The continued drop in vegetable prices and the lingering effects of reduced fuel and water tariffs suggest that inflationary pressures have eased significantly in the short term. The Colombo Consumer Price Index (CCPI) has deflated on a Year-on-Year (YoY) basis recording -0.5 percent in September 2024 (Vs 0.5 percent in August 2024).

Both market indices moved upwards. The All Share Price Index went up by 148.2 points while S and P SL20 rose by 52 points. Turnover stood at Rs 3.5 billion with nine crossings. Those crossings were reported in Sampath Bank, where 2 million shares crossed to the tune of Rs 156 million and its shares traded at Rs 78, CIC Holdings 1.9 million shares crossed for Rs 146 million; its shares traded at Rs 75, Dialog 14 million shares crossed for Rs 130 million; its shares traded at Rs 9.30, HNB 355,000 shares crossed for Rs 74.5 million; its shares sold at Rs 210, TJ Lanka 771,000 shares crossed for Rs 31.2 million and its shares price traded at Rs 31.2 million, Renuka Hotel (Non- Voting), 2.1 million shares crossed to the tune of Rs 31.2 million; its shares traded at Rs 11.50, Laugfs Power 2.5 million share volumes changed hands for 24.9 million; its shares fetched Rs 9.90, Pan Asian Bank 989,000 shares crossed to the tune of Rs 22.2 million; its shares traded at Rs 22.50 and Ambeon Holdings 500,000 shares crossed for Rs 20 million; its shares traded at Rs 40.

In the retail market, the top seven companies that mainly contributed to the turnover were; Sampath Bank Rs 433 million (5.5 million shares traded), HNB Rs 252 million (1.2 million shares traded), TJ Lanka Rs 166.9 million (four million shares traded), Commercial Bank Rs 148 million (1.4 million shares traded), JKH Rs 105 million (577,000 shares traded), Hayleys Fabrics Rs 84 million (1.7 million shares traded) and Hayleys Rs 81 million (800,000 shares traded). During the day 130 million share volumes changed hands in 18700 transactions. .
It is said that Banking sector counters, especially Sampath Bank and HNB performed well while the manufacturing sector, especially TJ Lanka performed well during the day.
Yesterday, the rupee appreciated to open at Rs 295.80/296.10 to the US dollar, from Rs 296.10/60 a day earlier, while bond yields were broadly steady, dealers said.

A bond maturing on 15.12.2027 was quoted at 11.60/80 percent, up from 11.60/75 percent. A bond maturing on 15.02.2028 was quoted at 11.92/98 percent, from 11.85/12.00 percent. A bond maturing on 15.06.2029 was quoted at 11.90/12.10 percent, from 11.90/12.00 percent.
